channel.title: NPR All Things Considered
channel.description: All Things Considered hosts Ailsa Chang, Mary Louise Kelly, Ari Shapiro, Juana Summers and Scott Detrow present the program's trademark mix of news, interviews, commentaries, reviews, and offbeat features 7 days a week.

item.title: Majority of Americans oppose ending birthright citizenship, NPR/Ipsos poll finds
item.description: As the Supreme Court takes up birthright citizenship, a new poll finds that less than a third of Americans want it to end. But other parts of the White House's immigration crackdown are more popular.

item.title: Some federal agencies dealing with DOGE cuts feel confusion and concern for the future
item.description: Reporters have been looking at federal agencies and employees impacted by DOGE cuts from food inspectors to nuclear scientists to firefighters, and the broader effects of the restructuring efforts.

item.title: Within the new novel 'The Emperor of Gladness,' a love letter to fast food workers
item.description: In his new novel, The Emperor of Gladness, Ocean Vuong lovingly describes characters who worked together in a Connecticut fast food restaurant.

item.title: A Democrat wins in red state Nebraska and becomes first elected Black mayor of Omaha
item.description: Omaha is considered a blue dot in the red state of Nebraska and now the city will have a new Democratic mayor. John Ewing, Jr., ousted a Republican incumbent and will be the first Black mayor.

item.title: Syrian aid group leader says U.S. lifting sanctions is historic moment
item.description: NPR's Juana Summers speaks with Mouaz Moustafa, executive director of the Syrian Emergency Task Force, about President Trump's decision to lift US sanctions against Syria.

item.title: Here to Help: Diaper bank volunteer
item.description: For one volunteer, helping get the basics out to new parents is an endorphin rush.

item.title: The 'Oscar' of food prizes goes to a Brazilian who harnessed the power of bacteria
item.description: This year's $500,000 World Food Prize, for advances in agriculture and nutrition, goes to a Brazilian who boosted the country's farming revolution, turning it into a soybean superpower.

item.title: Pete Rose has been reinstated by the MLB â€” meaning he's eligible for the Hall of Fame
item.description: Pete Rose was banned from the MLB for life in 1989 for betting on games as a manager and player, essentially dashing any hopes of him making it into the Hall of Fame. Now, his ban has been lifted.

item.title: RFK Jr. faces criticism from Congress about budget cuts to science and health care
item.description: On Wednesday, Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. testifys before the House Appropriations committee in the morning and the Senate HELP committee hearing in the evening.

item.title: Treasure worth $10,000 was hidden in San Francisco. And then someone found it
item.description: People ran around San Francisco on Tuesday looking for a chest filled with gold and local artifacts after seeing an anonymous post on Reddit with cryptic clues.
